questions.text: A patient who is a known case of angle-closure glaucoma has been diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Which of the following drugs have to be avoided in this patient? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amitriptyline

 

  • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that is known to have marked anticholinergic activity.
  • TCAs have high affinity for muscarinic acetylcholine (M type) receptors, causing the subsequent blockade of these receptors.
  • Blocking of these receptors can result in decreased outflow of aqueous humour, leading to an increase in intraocular pressure.
  • This effect can exacerbate pre-existing angle-closure type glaucoma, which is already characterized by impaired drainage of aqueous humour.
  • Therefore, amitriptyline is a drug to be avoided in patients with angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B and D: Sertraline and Fluvoxamine are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors with no activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors and therefore have no effect on the outflow of aqueous humor and thereby, on the intraocular pressure.

 

Option C: Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that is a serotonin-norephedrine reuptake inhibitor with the ability to precipitate angle-closure glaucoma by itself; however, due to lack of any activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors, it does not increase the intraocular pressure to the extent that Amitriptyline does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with angle-closure glaucoma, medications with anticholinergic properties, such as Amitriptyline, should be avoided due to their potential to increase intraocular pressure and exacerbate the condition.

questions.text: The rupture of penile urethra does not cause extravasation of blood into which of the following spaces? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deep perineal pouch

 

Option B. Deep perineal pouch: This is a space situated superior to the perineal membrane and inferior to the pelvic diaphragm. It contains the membranous urethra, deep transverse perineal muscles, and parts of the external urethral sphincter. Extravasation of urine is possible in deep perineal pouch.

 

When there is a rupture of the penile urethra (often due to trauma, such as a straddle injury), the extravasation of urine and blood can occur into various anatomical spaces, depending on the location and nature of the injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial perineal pouch: This is a space located in the urogenital triangle of the perineum, bounded above by the perineal membrane and below by the perineal (Colles') fascia. The pouch contains the root of the penis (including the bulb of the penis) and the associated muscles. A rupture of the penile urethra can cause extravasation of urine and blood into this space.

 

Option C. Skin around penis. The skin around base of penis may get involved if the rupture is located in the bulbous part of urethra.

 

Option D. Skin around the scrotum: With a rupture of the penile urethra, especially if the rupture occurs in the bulbous part located within the superficial perineal pouch, the extravasated urine and blood can dissect through the fascial layers and present as swelling and bruising around the scrotum and base of the penis. This is often referred to as a "butterfly" pattern of bruising, as the extravasated fluid can spread anteriorly onto the anterior abdominal wall and laterally to the thighs but is typically limited superiorly by Scarpa's fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rupture of the penile urethra causes extravasation of blood into the superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, penis, and then up to the lower anterior abdominal wall.

 

The membranous layer of superficial fascia attaches to the ischiopubic rami and forms the lateral borders of the urogenital triangle. Thus, the urine does not extravasate to the thigh.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of unexplained weight loss, hematuria, and a palpable abdominal mass. Imaging studies reveal a large renal mass. A renal biopsy has the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromophobe carcinoma

 

The clinical presentation and biopsy findings are consistent with chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Chromophobe RCC is characterized histologically by large polygonal cells with distinct cell borders, perinuclear halos, and a "plant-like" or "resinoid" nuclear appearance.

 

The biopsy image shows these classic features, which differentiate chromophobe RCC from other renal cancer variants.

 

While clear cell carcinoma is the most common type of RCC, the histological findings of clear cytoplasm with perinuclear clearing are more characteristic of chromophobe carcinoma. This variant is less aggressive compared to clear cell RCC and is often diagnosed with specific features on histopathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clear cell carcinoma: This is the most common type of RCC, characterized by cells with clear cytoplasm due to the presence of glycogen and lipid, which are dissolved during processing. The biopsy image does not show these clear cells, ruling out this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma: Papillary RCC is characterized by the presence of papillary structures and foamy macrophages. The biopsy image lacks these papillary features, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option D. Bellini duct carcinoma: Also known as collecting duct carcinoma, this rare and aggressive form of RCC shows infiltrative growth patterns with prominent desmoplastic reaction. The biopsy does not match these characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromophobe RCC is identified by cells with distinct borders, a plant-like or resinoid nucleus, and a perinuclear halo, distinguishing it from other RCC types.

questions.text: A 52-year-old lady develops sudden onset facial deviation with slurring of speech and inability to raise right arm. The symptoms spontaneously begin to reduce and has significant improvement over the next 48 hours. She has a mid-diastolic murmur on auscultation and irregular heart rhythm. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardio-embolic stroke

 

Explanation

 

The patient presents with sudden onset neurological deficits (facial deviation, slurred speech, and right arm weakness), which improved significantly over 48 hours. The presence of a mid-diastolic murmur suggests mitral stenosis, and the irregular heart rhythm indicates atrial fibrillation. These are strong risk factors for cardio-embolic stroke. Although the improvement suggests a transient ischemic attack (TIA), the symptoms lasted more than 24 hours, which aligns with the definition of a stroke rather than a TIA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TIA: By definition, a TIA's symptoms resolve within 24 hours. Since the symptoms persisted for more than 24 hours, this is not a TIA.

 

Option B. Thrombo-embolic stroke: While possible, the presence of mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation makes cardio-embolic stroke more likely.

 

Option D. Paradoxical embolism: This occurs when a thrombus from the venous system passes through a right-to-left cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale) into the arterial system. There is no mention of such a shunt or a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardio-embolic stroke should be suspected in patients with sudden onset neurological deficits and risk factors such as mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation. Symptoms persisting for more than 24 hours distinguish stroke from TIA.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male came to the emergency after sustaining an injury and was given 0.25% bupivacaine for regional anesthesia. A few minutes later, he became unresponsive and pulseless. What would be the ideal management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CPR & 20% IV Intralipid

 

The scenario describes a case of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur after the administration of local anesthetics like bupivacaine. LAST can cause severe cardiovascular and central nervous system toxicity, leading to symptoms such as seizures, coma, and cardiovascular collapse, as seen in this patient.

 

The management of LAST involves:

 

  1. Immediate initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) if the patient is unresponsive and pulseless.
  2. Administration of 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid). This treatment, known as lipid rescue or lipid emulsion therapy, acts by creating a "lipid sink" that absorbs the local anesthetic from the tissues and blood, reducing its toxic effects on the heart and brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CPR & Calcium gluconate: Calcium gluconate is not the primary treatment for local anesthetic toxicity. It is used in cases of hyperkalemia or calcium channel blocker overdose.

 

Option C. CPR & Start Dobutamine infusion: While dobutamine can support cardiac function, it is not specific for treating local anesthetic toxicity and does not address the underlying cause.

 

Option D. CPR & Start NaHCO3 infusion: Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat metabolic acidosis and certain poisonings, such as tricyclic antidepressant overdose, but it is not specific for local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), immediate management includes starting CPR and administering 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid) therapy. This approach helps to rapidly reduce the toxic effects of the local anesthetic on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.

choices.text: It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases
It shows Ad type of curve

questions.text: A patient has otitis media with effusion. Which of the following is wrong?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It shows Ad type of curve

 

Otitis media with effusion (OME) is a condition characterized by the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs or symptoms of acute ear infection. The incorrect statement regarding it is, It shows Ad type of curve. This statement is incorrect. OME typically shows a B type of tympanogram curve. A B type curve indicates the presence of middle ear fluid. An Ad type curve is associated with ossicular discontinuity, which is not related to OME.

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bilateral: Can be true but not mandatory; OME can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Option B. It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases: True, as the condition often resolves with the resolution of the underlying URTI.

 

Option C. It is associated with cold: True, as URTI and colds can lead to Eustachian tube dysfunction and subsequent fluid accumulation in the middle ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otitis media with effusion shows a B type of tympanogram curve, not an Ad type curve.

choices.text: Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout
Hyperventilation causing increased CO2 washout
Increased tubular reabsorption of HCO3-
Increased excretion of H+

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis findings of a patient are as follows pH= 7.30, HCO3= 10 mEq/L, paco2= 30 mmHg, which is suggestive of a partially compensated metabolic acidosis. What is the mechanism for the secondary disorder? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout

 

ABG shows pH 7.3 (acidosis) → Metabolic (HCO3- = 10)

 

Expected pCO2 = HCO3 +15 = 25 is < actual pCO2 (30) suggesting there is excess CO2 than expected. Hypoventilation leads to CO2 accumulation.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hyperventilation leads to excess CO2 washout: And would have reduced the pCO2 levels than the expected values.

 

Option C. Increased absorption of HCO3: Will lead to metabolic alkalosis.

 

Option D. Increased H+ excretion: Will lead to metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of metabolic acidosis, compare the actual respiratory response (PaCO2) with what is theoretically expected. Inadequate reduction in PaCO2, or relative hypoventilation, suggests partial compensation, highlighting a need for further intervention to correct the underlying acid-base disturbance.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient arrives at the hospital emergency department presenting with gastrointestinal distress. The patient complains of severe abdominal pain, frequent vomiting, and watery diarrhea. During the physical examination, the medical team observes that the patient's stools emit an unusual faint glow. The patient appears disoriented and fatigued. The medical history reveals that the patient attended a local festival the previous day and consumed various food items there. The following exposures might be contributing to which substance toxication? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phosphorus

 

The vomitus and stools turn luminescent in acute phosphorus poisoning.

 

The stools also release mild fumes and this is called ‘smoky stool syndrome’.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mercury: Symptoms: Tremors, memory loss, gingivitis, and gastrointestinal distress.

 

Option B. Cadmium: Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and renal damage.

 

Option D. Calcium: Symptoms: Hypercalcemia, muscle weakness, confusion, and abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparison of Poisoning Types:

questions.text: Following delivery, the placenta is being removed by traction on the  cord as shown in the image. The cord snaps and there is profuse bleeding. What is the next step in management?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Manual removal of placenta

 

  • Manual removal of placenta:
    • The maneuver shown in the image is the Brandt-Andrews maneuver, used in controlled cord traction for the delivery of the placenta.
    • If the umbilical cord snaps during this maneuver, it indicates a retained placenta, which can lead to profuse bleeding.
    • The immediate next step is manual removal of the placenta to prevent excessive hemorrhage and ensure that no parts of the placenta remain in the uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxytocin: While oxytocin is used to enhance uterine contractions and prevent postpartum hemorrhage, in this scenario, it is more critical to address the retained placenta immediately through manual removal.

 

Option B. Uterine massage: Uterine massage is beneficial in promoting uterine contractions and reducing bleeding, but it will not resolve the issue of the retained placenta.

 

Option C. Arrange blood and Crede’s method: Arranging blood is prudent for managing potential blood loss, but Crede’s method, which involves expulsion of the placenta by fundal pressure, is not recommended due to the risk of uterine inversion and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the umbilical cord snaps during controlled cord traction for placenta delivery, manual removal of the placenta is the immediate next step to prevent hemorrhage and ensure complete removal.

 

Ref: Page 1298, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant G3P2L2 woman presented to OBG department at 36 weeks of amenorrhea. Ultrasound shows that the fetus is in a transverse lie. The liquor is adequate, the placenta is normal, and she has no gross anomaly. Both her previous deliveries were normal vaginal deliveries. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External cephalic version

 

In this situation, external cephalic version should be attempted.

 

Management of Transverse lie –

 

 

Absolute Contraindications of ECV:

 

  • Placenta Previa
  • Contracted Pelvis
  • Multiple Pregnancy
  • Hyperextended head
  • Uterine Anomaly
  • Dead fetus
  • Distressed fetus
  • Denied consent

 

Complications of ECV:

 

  • Abruption
  • Rupture of membranes
  • Preterm labour.
  • Fetal distress.
  • Cord presentation or prolapse
  • Entangling of the cord around the fetus.
  • Isoimmunization in Rh-negative mothers due to feto-maternal transfusion.
  • Induction of labor is contraindicated in Transverse lie.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cesarean section: While a cesarean section is the best and safest method of delivery in cases of persistent transverse or oblique lie, it is not the first-line management in this situation where ECV can be attempted.

 

Option C. Expectant management: Waiting for spontaneous correction is not recommended at 36 weeks with a transverse lie, as it may not occur, and could lead to complications.

 

Option D. Induction of labor: Inducing labor in a transverse lie position is contraindicated as it can lead to complications such as cord prolapse and obstructed labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External cephalic version should be attempted between 36 and 37 weeks of gestation for a fetus in a transverse lie if there are no contraindications.

questions.text: Choose the best option to define a post-term neonate: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Born after 42 weeks of gestation

 

Post-term neonates are those who are born after 42 weeks / 294 days of gestation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Based on the above table

 

Option A. Born after 37 weeks of gestation:  early term (37 to 38 6/7  )

 

Option B. Born after 40 weeks of gestation: Late term between 41 to 41 6/7 and  Full term: between 39 to 40 6/7  and

 

Option D. Born between 37 – 40 weeks of gestation: Term pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-term neonates are those who are born after 42 weeks / 294 days of gestation.

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, chapter on preterm labor

choices.text: 2 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart
2 doses of 12 mg given 24 hours apart
4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart
4 doses of 12 mg given 12 hours apart

questions.text: What is the dose of dexamethasone given for fetal lung maturity? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart

 

Explanation:


For fetal lung maturity, dexamethasone is administered to help reduce the risks associated with premature birth by promoting the development of the fetal lungs. The recommended regimen for dexamethasone is:

 

  • 4 doses of 6 mg each administered intramuscularly every 12 hours.

 

This dosing schedule is intended to maximize the benefit of corticosteroids in promoting fetal lung maturity and reducing the incidence of complications associated with preterm birth, such as respiratory distress syndrome, intraventricular hemorrhage, necrotizing enterocolitis, and the need for ventilatory support.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart: Incorrect. This dosing regimen is not the standard for dexamethasone. The correct regimen involves 4 doses of 6 mg.

 

Option B. 2 doses of 12 mg given 24 hours apart: Incorrect. This regimen is used for betamethasone, not dexamethasone. The standard for dexamethasone is 4 doses of 6 mg.

 

Option D. 4 doses of 12 mg given 12 hours apart: Incorrect. The correct dosing for dexamethasone is 6 mg per dose, not 12 mg.

 

Educational Objective:


For fetal lung maturity, the recommended dose of dexamethasone is 4 doses of 6 mg given intramuscularly every 12 hours.

 

Ref: Page no 2088, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Treatment of this condition in a pregnant female would be? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

The condition shown in the image is condyloma acuminatum, also known as genital warts, caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).

 

In pregnant females, the treatment options are limited due to potential teratogenic effects of certain medications. Cryotherapy is considered safe and effective for treating genital warts during pregnancy. If cryotherapy is not an option, trichloroacetic acid can also be used safely.

 

If the women is not Pregnant then Podophyllin can be given

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Podophyllin: This medication is teratogenic and should be avoided in pregnant women.

 

Option B. Imiquimod: Safety studies on the use of imiquimod during pregnancy are lacking, so it is also avoided in pregnant females.

 

Option D. Surgical excision: This is generally reserved for very large genital warts, such as Buschke-Löwenstein tumors, and is not the first-line treatment for typical cases of condyloma acuminatum in pregnant females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant females with condyloma acuminatum, cryotherapy is the preferred treatment due to its safety profile, while teratogenic treatments like podophyllin and those with uncertain safety like imiquimod should be avoided.

choices.text: Prescribe an abdominal belt for the daily use
Advise observations and reassessment in 6 months

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient, who underwent midline laparotomy for colonic cancer one month ago, presents with a palpable abdominal bulge at the surgical site. Physical examination reveals a reducible midline incisional hernia of 12cm. What is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schedule for laparoscopic mesh repair 

 

For a patient with a palpable abdominal bulge at the site of a recent surgical incision, indicative of an incisional hernia, management options vary depending on the size of the hernia, symptoms, and the patient's overall health status. 

 

This is a minimally invasive approach that is commonly used for large ventral hernias like in this case. The use of mesh is associated with a lower rate of recurrence compared to suture repair alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prescribe an abdominal belt for daily use: While an abdominal belt or binder can provide temporary relief and support for a hernia, it does not correct the underlying issue. It is more of a conservative approach and may be considered in patients who are not candidates for surgery.

 

Option C. Advise observations and reassessment in 6 months: Observation may be appropriate for small, asymptomatic hernias or in patients where surgery poses a high risk. However, given the size of the hernia (12 cm), this approach could lead to an increased risk of complications such as incarceration or strangulation.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic closure without mesh: Closing the hernia laparoscopically without mesh is less favored for larger hernias due to higher recurrence rates compared to mesh repair.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most appropriate next step in the management of a patient with a large, reducible midline incisional hernia is to schedule a laparoscopic mesh repair, which offers a minimally invasive approach with a lower risk of recurrence.

questions.text: A patient who has taken the first COVID vaccine comes for the second dose. An astute nurse noticed that the shoulder was flabby, flat, and was asymmetrical. There was an associated loss of contour of the shoulder joint. Injury to which of the structures might have resulted and was avoidable?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Axillary nerve

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of injury to axillary nerve which leads to deltoid muscle palsy.

 

The deltoid muscle is supplied by the axillary nerve. Iatrogenic damage to the axillary nerve can happen during transaxillary procedures on the shoulder with lateral deltoid-splitting incisions or while administering IM injections inappropriately. But, note that this nerve is commonly injured during shoulder dislocation (most commonly anterior type) or fractures of the humeral neck as both the nerve and the posterior circumflex vessels (pass horizontally and posterior to the neck of the humerus).

 

 

Injury to the axillary nerve can lead to:

 

  • Weakness of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm
  • Retropulsion (extension of the shoulder with the arm abducted to 90 degrees) is impossible.
  • Atrophy of the Deltoid muscle leading to the loss of muscle contours of the shoulder
  • Loss of sensation in the Regimental badge area

 

The described symptoms point towards a condition known as "Shoulder Injury Related to Vaccine Administration" (SIRVA). SIRVA can occur if the vaccine is injected too high in the upper arm, potentially causing inflammation or damage to the structures underlying the deltoid muscle, especially the axillary nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotator Cuff: The rotator cuff is a group of four muscles (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis) that stabilize and allow various movements of the shoulder joint. Injury to the rotator cuff often results from trauma, repetitive use, or degeneration and leads to pain, especially with overhead activities, and weakness in the arm. A rotator cuff injury would not typically cause the "flabby, flat, asymmetrical" appearance described unless there was a significant tear and muscle atrophy. However, this type of injury wouldn't be directly associated with vaccine administration.

 

Option B. Posterior Circumflex Artery: The posterior circumflex humeral artery is a branch of the axillary artery that runs posteriorly around the surgical neck of the humerus. Injury to this artery might result in bleeding and potentially hematoma formation but wouldn't lead to the described flabby, flat appearance of the shoulder or loss of contour.

 

Option C. Lateral Cutaneous Nerve of Arm: The lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm, also known as the lateral brachial cutaneous nerve, is a sensory nerve that provides sensation to the lateral part of the upper arm. Injury to this nerve would result in sensory loss or tingling in its distribution area but would not cause the observed morphological changes or affect the contour of the shoulder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and supplies the deltoid muscle and the teres minor muscle. It also carries sensory fibers for the skin over a part of the deltoid (known as the "regimental badge area").

 

Damage to the axillary nerve can result from shoulder dislocations or, as in this case, a vaccine administered too high on the arm. Injury to the axillary nerve would cause paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to a flat shoulder appearance and loss of the normal rounded contour of the deltoid. Over time, if the nerve does not recover, the deltoid muscle may atrophy, further accentuating the flat appearance.

questions.text: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sandfly

 

The image shown is of the Leishman-Donovan bodies whose presence are diagnostic of Kala Azar. The vector of Kala Azar is a sandfly.

 

Leishman-Donovan bodies are amastigotes with a double dot appearance containing a nucleus and small rodlike kinetoplast. They are present inside the macrophage.

 

The sandfly serves as the vector for Leishmania parasites. When a sandfly bites a human, it can transmit the parasites which then proliferate within the host's macrophages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anopheles mosquito: Incorrect, as this mosquito is the vector for malaria, not Kala Azar.

 

Option B. Ixodes Tick: Incorrect, this tick is a vector for diseases like Lyme disease and not for Kala Azar.

 

Option D. Tsetse fly: Incorrect, as Tsetse flies transmit trypanosomes that cause sleeping sickness, not Leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The presence of Leishman-Donovan bodies inside macrophages is indicative of Kala Azar, a severe form of leishmaniasis transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. Effective prevention and control are critical in endemic regions to reduce the transmission and impact of this disease.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia, and painful eye movements. What could be the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B deficiency

 

Vitamin B deficiency: This is the correct answer. The symptoms given in question are suggestive of Wernicke encephalopathy, which is caused by vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is caused by a deficiency in vitamin B1 (thiamine). Chronic alcoholism can lead to thiamine deficiency, which results in neurological symptoms like those described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A deficiency: Vitamin A deficiency typically presents with different symptoms, such as night blindness and skin issues, and is not related to the neurological symptoms seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option C. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to various bone related problems like Rickets and Osteomalacia, but it is not associated with the specific symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and painful eye movements seen in this case.

 

Option D. Vitamin C deficiency: Vitamin C deficiency, also known as scurvy, primarily presents with symptoms like fatigue, joint pain, and bleeding gums. It is not related to the neurological symptoms described in the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke encephalopathy – An acute, reversible but life-threatening condition. Clinical Vignette include Confusion, Ophthalmoplegia, Nystagmus, Ataxia.

choices.text: The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reasons is independently a false statement.
The assertion is independently a false statement, but the reasons is independently a true statement.
Both assertion and reason are true statements
Both assertion and reason are false statements

questions.text:
Assertion: Resting membrane potential is dependent on proteins and phosphate ions.

 

Reason: Diffusion potential can be calculated using Nernst Equation. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are true statements

 

Resting membrane potential refers to the electrical charge difference across the cell membrane of a neuron or other excitable cells when the cell is at rest, meaning it is not actively transmitting signals. This potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions, across the cell membrane.

 

Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

 

 

Where:

 

  • E is the equilibrium potential for the ion.
  • R is the ideal gas constant.
  • T is the absolute temperature (in Kelvin).
  • z is the valence (charge) of the ion.
  • F is Faraday's constant.
  • [Cout]​ and [Cin]​ are the concentrations of the ion outside and inside the membrane, respectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Resting membrane potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions (including proteins and phosphate ions), across the cell membrane.
  • The Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

questions.text: A dwarf female patient brought to the hospital with a history of primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely placed nipples. What is the most common karyotype associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 45X0

 

Explanation

 

The presentation of a dwarf female patient with primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely spaced nipples is characteristic of Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, most commonly represented by the karyotype 45X0. This syndrome is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Turner syndrome, characterized by the karyotype 45X0, is the most common chromosomal disorder associated with features such as primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely spaced nipples in females.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state.
  • TED may be associated with Graves’ disease, hypothyroidism, or euthyroidism, and the direct causative connection between thyroid dysfunction and ocular changes is unclear.
  • Main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with painful eye movements, periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia.

 

Option C. Orbital lymphoma: Usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.

 

Option D. Orbital cellulitis: Is usually U/L condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis

 

NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

THYROID OPHTHALMOPATHY EYE SIGNS:

  1. Stellwag sign- incomplete and frequent blinking
  2. Gifford sign- difficulty while everting the upper eyelid
  3. Jellinek sign- abnormal pigmentation of upper eyelid
  4. Enroth sign- lower eyelid edema
  5. Griffith sign- lid lag on upgaze
  6. Mobius sign- not able to converge eyes
  7. Ballet's sign- one or more extraocular muscle restriction
  8. Von graefe sign- retarded descent of upper lid in downgaze
  9. Joffrey sign- absent crease of the forehead in superior gaze
  10. Kocher's sign- staring and frightened appearance of eyes
  11. Dalyrymple sign- eyelid retraction

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing the storage conditions of various vaccines in a rural health center. She wants to ensure that all the vaccines have been stored appropriately and have not been exposed to temperatures outside the recommended range. She is looking for a specific indicator on the vaccine vials that shows the cumulative heat exposure over time. Which of the following is the correct indicator she should check? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) VVM

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.
  • A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.
  • Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.
  • If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) as the correct tool used to indicate the cumulative heat exposure of vaccines over time, ensuring their potency and safe use.

questions.text: A child presents with mental retardation, bone pain, and inability to walk. On fundoscopy examination, a cherry red spot is seen. There is no organomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tay-Sachs disease

 

Tay-Sachs disease. The given clinical scenario, along with the fundoscopy image showing a macular cherry-red spot, indicates that the most likely diagnosis is Tay-Sachs disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niemann-Pick disease: Niemann-Pick disease is another lysosomal storage disorder, but it often presents with hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen), which is not mentioned in the case. The cherry-red spot is not a typical feature of Niemann-Pick disease.

 

Option C. Hurler syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis I), autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs. Enzyme deficient is α-L-Iduronidase. Presents usually at 6-24 months with clouded cornea, coarse facial features, joint stiffness, and skeletal dysplasia. Glaucoma, retinal degeneration, and nasal discharge are the other features. The condition is generally fatal.

 

Option D. Gaucher’s Disease presents with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance. Mental Retardation is not seen.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 1-week-old child was presented with early cataract. He also has refusal to feed, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis. This can be caused due to the deficiency of which enzyme? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase

 

The clinical presentation described in the question is characteristic of classic galactosemia, a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT). This enzyme deficiency leads to an accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate, which causes toxicity, especially in the liver, kidney, and lens of the eye.

 

The symptoms presented in the question are early cataract, refusal to feed, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis—are typical of galactosemia. The cataract seen in these patients is often described as an "," which is due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens, a metabolite of galactose.

 

 

Galactosemia can be of three types:

 

  • Type 1: Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency (most common and severe form).
  • Type 2: Galactokinase deficiency.
  • Type 3: UDP-galactose-4-epimerase deficiency.

 

Among these, Type 1 galactosemia (GALT deficiency) is responsible for the symptoms described and is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. It is not associated with galactose metabolism or the symptoms described, making this an incorrect choice.

 

Option C. Aldose reductase: Aldose reductase converts galactose to galactitol in the lens, contributing to cataract formation in patients with galactosemia. However, the enzyme's deficiency is not the primary cause of the described condition; instead, its action exacerbates the effects of galactosemia.

 

Option D. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is involved in the phosphorylation of glucose, not galactose. It plays no direct role in the pathogenesis of galactosemia or the symptoms mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase and presents with early cataracts, feeding difficulties, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis in newborns.

questions.text: Relieving pressure of pop off valve in this device is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30-40 cm H2O 

 

The image shows an Ambu bag, which is used to provide positive pressure ventilation to patients. The pop-off valve, also known as a pressure release valve, is a safety feature that prevents the delivery of excessive pressure to the patient's lungs. This valve is typically set to relieve pressure at 30-40 cm H2O, which is sufficient to ventilate the patient without causing barotrauma, which is damage to the lungs from excessive pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pop-off valve in a manual resuscitator is typically set to relieve pressure at 30-40 cm H2O to ensure safe and effective ventilation without causing lung damage.

questions.text: A patient presented with dermatitis and loss of appetite. He also gives a frequent history of diarrhoea. On examination, alopecia also seen and patient has observed that he has delayed wound healing. This patient is most likely to have deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zinc

 

Zinc deficiency can cause a range of symptoms, including dermatitis, alopecia, loss of appetite, impaired immune function leading to frequent infections, and poor wound healing. Zinc is crucial for skin health, immune function, and overall protein synthesis, explaining the diverse symptoms including skin issues and gastrointestinal disturbances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C: While Vitamin C deficiency, known as scurvy, can lead to poor wound healing and gum bleeding, it does not typically cause dermatitis or alopecia. The primary features of scurvy are related to its role in collagen synthesis, including skin bruising, bleeding gums, and joint pain.

 

Option C. Vitamin D: Deficiency in Vitamin D commonly leads to bone-related problems like rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. It does not typically present with dermatitis, alopecia, or gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Niacin deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by the "three Ds": Dermatitis, Diarrhea, and Dementia. While some symptoms overlap, such as dermatitis and diarrhea, pellagra is typically associated with neurological symptoms and doesn't usually include alopecia or delayed wound healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The symptoms described, including dermatitis, loss of appetite, diarrhea, alopecia, and delayed wound healing, are consistent with a disease known as Acrodermatitis Enteropathica due to zinc deficiency. Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including immune function, wound healing, and maintenance of skin and hair. Symptoms of this disease are:

 

  • Simultaneous diarrhoea + dermatitis
  • Inflammation around nose, mouth, anus, cheeks, elbow etc.
  • It also occurs in some infants after weaning from breast milk as breast milk has picolinic acid (piconilic acid increases Zn absorption from intestine)           

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Medical biochemistry 3rd edition Page no. 414

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic pancreatitis

 

Chronic pancreatitis is characterized by the presence of calcifications along the pancreas, which is a hallmark sign visible on imaging. The X-ray shows calcification along the pancreas, which is indicative of chronic inflammation and fibrosis due to ongoing damage to the pancreatic tissue. These calcifications are a classic sign of chronic pancreatitis and help differentiate it from other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wolman disease: Wolman disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by calcifications in the adrenal glands due to a deficiency in lysosomal acid lipase. The calcifications in Wolman disease appear near the adrenal glands, which are located superiorly to the kidneys, rather than along the pancreas.

 

Option C. Acute pancreatitis: Acute pancreatitis typically presents with inflammation of the pancreas but does not usually involve calcification. Acute cases are seen with other signs of inflammation like fluid collections but not chronic calcifications.

 

Option D. TB Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis rarely shows calcification on a plain abdominal X-ray unless there is involvement of specific abdominal lymph nodes or organ involvement like the adrenal glands. Pancreatic calcification is not a typical feature of TB.

 

Educational Objective:


Chronic pancreatitis is characterized by pancreatic calcifications on imaging, which are absent in acute pancreatitis and other conditions like Wolman disease or TB.

questions.text: In which trimester does acute fatty liver manifest most commonly during pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Third trimester

 

Explanation:

 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is a life-threatening medical disorder involving the liver. It most commonly manifests during the late second and third trimester of pregnancy. The diagnosis is made by the Swansea Criteria, wherein 6 or more of the following are required to make the diagnosis:

 

  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Polydipsia, polyuria
  • Encephalopathy
  • Coagulopathy (raised PT, aPTT)
  • Increased bilirubin
  • Increased uric acid levels
  • Increased creatinine
  • Leukocytosis
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Raised liver enzymes
  • Raised serum ammonia levels
  • Ascites or bright liver on ultrasound
  • Microvascular steatosis on liver biopsy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) most commonly manifests during the third trimester of pregnancy and is diagnosed using the Swansea Criteria.

 

Ref: Page no 2684, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with rhinitis and swelling of the face. Intranasal biopsy revealed the presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching. There was evidence of vascular invasion. What will be the preferred treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amphotericin B

 

The clinical presentation and biopsy findings of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching and evidence of vascular invasion are characteristic of mucormycosis, a serious fungal infection commonly seen in diabetic patients and other immunocompromised individuals. Amphotericin B is the preferred initial treatment for mucormycosis due to its broad antifungal coverage and effectiveness against Mucorales, the group of fungi responsible for this infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used primarily for Candida and Cryptococcus infections. It is not effective against Mucorales and therefore not suitable for treating mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is another antifungal agent with a broad spectrum of action but has limited use due to its side effects and is not effective against Mucorales, making it inappropriate for mucormycosis treatment.

 

Option D. Griseofulvin: Griseofulvin is used for dermatophyte infections (e.g., tinea infections) and is not effective against Mucorales. It is not suitable for treating mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Mucormycosis:

 

  • Mucormycosis is a serious fungal infection that requires prompt and aggressive treatment due to its rapid progression and high mortality rate.
  • The mainstay of treatment is intravenous Amphotericin B, often followed by oral posaconazole or isavuconazole for maintenance therapy.
  • Surgical debridement of infected tissue is frequently necessary.
  • Controlling underlying conditions like diabetes is also crucial in managing mucormycosis.

questions.text: The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Allograft arteriopathy

 

The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is allograft arteriopathy.

 

Allograft arteriopathy: It is the single most important long-term limitation for cardiac transplantation. It is a late, progressive, diffusely stenosing intimal proliferation in the coronary arteries, leading to ischemic injury. It can lead to silent myocardial infarction since transplant patients have denervated hearts and do not experience angina. Progressive congestive heart failure and sudden cardiac death can also occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Complications following cardiac transplantation:

 

Option A. Allograft rejection: It is the primary concern that requires close surveillance. Both classic cellular rejection and antibody-mediated rejection is recognized. Cellular rejection is characterized by interstitial lymphocytic inflammation, with associated myocyte damage.

 

Option C. Infection: Infection is common in organ transplant recipients. Bacteria and viruses account for more than 80% of infections after transplantation. The most common bacterial infections early after transplantation are nosocomial, caused by infected intravascular catheters or lines, or gram-negative pneumonias.

 

Renal dysfunction- Immunosuppressive therapy with calcineurin inhibitors has improved both graft function and survival in heart transplantation.

 

Option D. Malignancy: Following heart transplantation, malignancy is identified in 3% to 18% of the recipients, with an estimated risk of 1% to 2% per year. It ranks second to coronary vasculopathy as a major cause of mortality, accounting for 10% to 23% of all deaths following heart transplantation. Cutaneous malignancy is the most common type with a predominance of squamous cell carcinoma. Post-transplantation lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) is a frequently fatal complication, the peak occurrence of PTLD is 3 to 4 months after transplantation. A strong association of PTLD with Epstein-Barr virus has been observed in several series.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allograft arteriopathy is the foremost long-term limitation in cardiac transplantation, causing significant morbidity and mortality through progressive coronary stenosis.

questions.text: Identify the structure in the following histological image: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Glomerulus

 

The above histology image shows the glomerulus of a nephron.

 

Glomerulus is a tuft of capillaries located within Bowman's capsule in the renal cortex of the kidney. Here are the key histological features of the glomerulus:

 

  • Capillary Endothelium: The innermost layer of the glomerulus consists of fenestrated endothelial cells. These fenestrations or pores allow plasma (minus the larger proteins) to move from the blood into Bowman's space.
  • Basement Membrane: Surrounding the endothelial cells is the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). It is a specialized extracellular matrix made up of type IV collagen, laminin, proteoglycans, and other glycoproteins. The GBM serves as a filter, preventing the passage of large proteins and cells but allowing smaller molecules to pass through.
  • Podocytes: These specialized epithelial cells cover the outer surface of the glomerular capillaries. They have foot processes called "pedicels" which interdigitate with one another, leaving filtration slits between them. The slit diaphragm, formed by intercellular junctions between adjacent pedicels, provides an additional barrier to the filtration of plasma proteins.
  • Mesangial Cells: Located between the capillaries of the glomerulus, mesangial cells have phagocytic activity and help in the structural support of the capillaries. They can also contract, thus regulating the blood flow through the glomerulus. Additionally, mesangial cells produce extracellular matrix components.
  • Juxtaglomerular Cells: These specialized smooth muscle cells are found in the afferent arteriole at the point of entry into the glomerulus. They secrete renin, a crucial enzyme in the renin-angiotensin system which regulates blood pressure.
  • Macula Densa: Although not a part of the glomerulus, the macula densa is closely related. It is a group of tall, closely packed cells in the distal convoluted tubule that detect changes in the sodium chloride levels in the filtrate and communicate with the juxtaglomerular cells to regulate renin secretion.
  • Bowman's Capsule: This is a double-layered capsule that surrounds the glomerulus. The inner layer, or visceral layer, is composed of podocytes. The outer layer, or parietal layer, is made up of a simple squamous epithelium. Between these two layers is the Bowman's space, into which the filtrate from the blood accumulates before moving into the renal tubules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leydig Cells, also known as interstitial cells of Leydig, are present in the interstitial connective between seminiferous tubules.

 

The testis contains numerous seminiferous tubules separated by connective tissue in between.

 

Seminiferous tubules are lined by several spermatogonia cells, which produce spermatozoa, and Sertoli (sustentacular) cells, which have a supportive function.The connective tissue in between the tubules is made up of Leydig cells, collagen fibers, fibroblasts, macrophages, mast cells, blood vessels, and lymphatics. Leydig cells are large, round, or polyhedral cells with eccentric nuclei. They are lightly stained and often have a foamy appearance. They secrete testosterone upon stimulation by luteinizing hormone from the anterior pituitary.

 

The image below shows seminiferous tubules and Leydig cells

 

 

Option B: Islets of Langerhans makes up the endocrine part of the pancreas.

 

Islets are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers and contain numerous fenestrated capillaries. There is a delicate capsule around each islet. The islet cells are paler than the surrounding exocrine cells, as they have less rough endoplasmic reticulum.

 

﻿﻿ The islet of Langerhans is mainly composed of three types of cells:

 

  • α or A cells - located peripherally and secrete glucagon
  • β or B cells - located centrally and produce insulin
  • δ or D cells - scattered between beta cells and secrete somatostatin

 

The image given below shows the islets of Langerhans

 

 

Option C: The thymic medulla contains fewer lymphocytes than the cortex, and the epithelial cells (E) located here have different morphology and function. The most characteristic feature of the medulla in humans is the presence of thymic (Hassall) corpuscles (H). These are of variable size and contain aggregates of thymic epithelial cells releasing many cytokines important within the medullary microenvironment, especially for dendritic cell activity and for the differentiation of regulatory T cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The glomerulus consists of a network of capillaries encased within Bowman's capsule, playing a key role in blood filtration.

choices.text: Rickettsia rickettsii
Rickettsia conorii
Anaplasma phagocytophilum

questions.text: The inclusion body Rickettsial morula is found in neutrophils during infection caused by? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anaplasma phagocytophilum

 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum is a bacterium known to cause the disease tick-borne fever (TBF) in domestic ruminants in Ixodes ricinus-infested areas in northern Europe. This organism infects granulocytes, particularly neutrophils, leading to the formation of characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies known as morulae.

 

During an infection with Anaplasma phagocytophilum, light microscopy of blood smears taken in the initial fever period can often suffice for diagnosis. When these blood smears are stained with May-Grünwald Giemsa, the organisms appear as blue cytoplasmic inclusions within the neutrophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia rickettsii: This bacterium causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever, which does not typically involve the formation of morulae in neutrophils. Instead, it causes endothelial cell infection leading to vasculitis.

 

Option B. Rickettsia conorii: The causative agent of Mediterranean spotted fever, also does not typically form morulae in neutrophils. Like R. rickettsii, it primarily infects endothelial cells.

 

Option D. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: This bacterium causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME) and forms morulae in monocytes, not neutrophils. This distinguishes it from Anaplasma phagocytophilum, which targets neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum causes the formation of Rickettsial morulae in neutrophils, whereas Ehrlichia chaffeensis forms morulae in monocytes.

 

Mnemonic "GAME": Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis.

questions.text: Match the following cancers with their corresponding criteria for the minimum number of lymph nodes required for pathological staging: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

The minimum number of lymph nodes required for accurate staging are 16 for stomach carcinoma, 12 for colon carcinoma, 6 for gall bladder carcinoma, and 10 for breast carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Abscess

 

The provided MRI images show a ring-enhancing lesion with bright white areas on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI), which indicates diffusion restriction. Diffusion restriction on DWI is characteristic of a brain abscess. Brain abscesses typically appear as ring-enhancing lesions with diffusion restriction due to the presence of pus, which restricts the movement of water molecules. The absence of bony structures and clear visualization of the brain on the MRI sequence also confirm that this is a DWI image, where bright areas represent restricted diffusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculomas: Tuberculomas often present as multiple ring-enhancing lesions that may conglomerate, and do not show the same characteristic diffusion restriction seen in abscesses. They have a different imaging pattern and usually do not exhibit a single, well-defined ring-enhancing lesion with prominent diffusion restriction.

 

Option C. Cryptococcomas: These lesions are commonly found in the basal ganglia and have a soap-bubble appearance rather than a ring enhancement. Cryptococcomas are typically not associated with the intense diffusion restriction seen in abscesses.

 

Option D. NCC (Neurocysticercosis): NCC lesions often have a characteristic central scolex, which is not visible in this image. The presence of a scolex is a key feature for diagnosing NCC, and the absence of this finding makes NCC less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brain abscesses present as ring-enhancing lesions with diffusion restriction on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI), appearing bright white on DWI due to restricted water movement caused by pus accumulation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old lady presents to the OPD with resting tremors, bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity and postural instability. After some time she died due to respiratory failure following pneumonia. Which of the following is expected to be seen in his brain biopsy? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lewy bodies

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation described is the characteristic of Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder affecting the central nervous system. The cardinal features of Parkinson's disease mentioned in the question are:

 

  1. Resting tremors: Tremors that occur when the affected body part is at rest and disappear with voluntary movement. These are often described as "pill-rolling" tremors.
  2. Bradykinesia: Slowness of movement and difficulty initiating movements.
  3. Cogwheel rigidity: A type of rigidity characterized by jerky, ratchet-like resistance to passive movement of a joint, resembling the clicking of a cogwheel.
  4. Postural instability: Impaired balance and coordination, leading to an increased risk of falls.

 

Parkinson's disease is caused by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta of the midbrain, leading to a deficiency of dopamine in the nigrostriatal pathway. The hallmark histopathological finding in Parkinson's disease is the presence of Lewy bodies in the affected neurons.

 

Lewy bodies are eosinophilic, round to elongated intracytoplasmic inclusions composed of aggregated proteins, primarily alpha-synuclein. They are considered the pathological hallmark of Parkinson's disease and other related disorders, collectively known as synucleinopathies.

 

 

The patient's death due to respiratory failure following pneumonia is a common complication in advanced stages of Parkinson's disease, as the disease progression can lead to impaired swallowing and increased risk of aspiration pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Negri bodies: These are intracytoplasmic inclusions found in the neurons of animals and humans infected with rabies virus. They are not associated with Parkinson's disease.

 

 

Option C. Hirano bodies: These are eosinophilic, rod-shaped intracytoplasmic inclusions found in the neurons of patients with neurodegenerative disorders, particularly Alzheimer's disease. They are not specific to Parkinson's disease.

 

 

Option D. Heinz bodies: These are intracellular inclusions found in red blood cells of individuals with various hemolytic anemias, such as glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. They are not related to Parkinson's disease or other neurodegenerative disorders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lewy bodies are the characteristic histopathological finding in the brain of patients with Parkinson's disease. Their presence, along with the clinical triad of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and rigidity, confirms the diagnosis of Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: A patient with a history of facial trauma, presented with diplopia, epistaxis, and restricted eye movements. Looking at the CT image given below, what will be your diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Blow-out fracture

 

The given clinical scenario plus CT image suggests a blowout fracture.

 

Orbital blowout fractures:

  • Result from trauma to the orbit.
  • Mainly involve orbital floor and medial wall.
  • Clinical signs:
  • Periocular swelling (early stage)
  • Subcutaneous emphysema affecting the eyelids (commoner with medial wall fractures)
  • Enophthalmus (inward displacement of eyeball) and mechanical ptosis
  • Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia
  • Double diplopia (diplopia in both upwards as well as downwards gaze)
  • The muscle restriction is confirmed with a positive “forced duction test”.

 

Forced Duction Test:

  • It is used to determine whether the absence of movement of eye is due to paralysis of extraocular muscles or due to mechanical obstruction.
  • To perform this test, anaesthetized conjunctiva, is grasped with forceps.
  • Now, an attempt is made to move the eyeball in the direction where the movement is restricted.
  • POSITIVE forced duction test: If it is due to mechanical obstruction, it will not be possible to move the eyeball.
  • NEGATIVE forced duction test: If it is due to paralytic squint, eyeball can move.
  • Investigations:
    • Waters view in x-ray shows a teardrop opacity.
    • CT scan is used for confirmation of diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Initial management is to prevent further injury to the globe.
    • Surgical indications:
    • Enophthalmos
    • Diplopia
    • Ocular motility disorder
    • Immediate repair indicated if oculocardiac reflex or significant enophthalmos is present.
    • Delayed repair is done within 2 weeks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Le-Fort fracture: Involves fractures of the maxillary bones and may present with midfacial mobility, but not typically with the specific signs of blow-out fractures.

 

Option B. Fracture maxilla: May involve the upper jaw but not specifically associated with the orbital floor fractures seen in blow-out fractures.

 

Option C. Fracture zygomatic: Involves the cheekbone and can cause facial asymmetry and infraorbital anesthesia, but typically does not cause the specific signs of a blow-out fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blow-out fracture, typically resulting from orbital trauma, is characterized by periocular swelling, subcutaneous emphysema, enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. The diagnosis is confirmed by a CT scan showing the characteristic teardrop sign.

choices.text: Two or more iris hamartomas
Acoustic neuromas
Dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone

questions.text: Which one of the following is not included in the criteria for neurofibromatosis 1? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acoustic neuromas 

 

In neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1), two or more of the following clinical manifestations are present:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acoustic neuromas are not a diagnostic criterion for Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1); they are typically associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2). The diagnostic criteria for NF1 include the presence of café-au-lait macules, axillary or inguinal freckling, Lisch nodules, neurofibromas, sphenoid dysplasia, optic gliomas, and a first-degree relative with NF1.

questions.text: In MSUD (Maple Syrup Urine disorder) which of the following is not restricted:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methionine

 

  • Methionine is not restricted in MSUD. MSUD is characterized by the inability to break down three specific branched-chain amino acids: Leucine, Isoleucine, and Valine. Methionine is not one of the amino acids that are restricted in the diet of individuals with MSUD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valine: Valine is one of the amino acids restricted in MSUD. People with MSUD need to limit their intake of Valine as their bodies cannot properly metabolize it.

 

Option C. Leucine: Leucine is another amino acid that is restricted in MSUD. It is one of the three branched-chain amino acids that individuals with MSUD need to limit in their diet.

 

Option D. Isoleucine: Isoleucine is also restricted in MSUD. Like Valine and Leucine, Isoleucine is a branched-chain amino acid that individuals with MSUD need to restrict to manage the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched Chain Keto-acid Decarboxylase resulting in defect in oxidative decarboxylation and catabolism of branched chain amino acids Valine, Isoleucine and leucine. As a result, these amino acids accumulate and are excreted in urine. So, for the treatment, these BCAA should be restricted in diet.

 

Methionine is a sulphur containing amino acid and do not require this enzyme for its metabolism. So, its restriction is not required in MSUD.  

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 290

questions.text: A ten-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with fever and swelling of hands after playing football. He gives a history of previous episodes of swelling of hands. On imaging, his spleen was found to be shrunken. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sickle cell anemia

 

History is suggestive of dactylitis precipitated by playing causing microvascular obstruction. Shrunken spleen suggestive of auto splenectomy with recurrent episodes of dactylitis suggests sickle cell anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria: Typically presents with cyclical fever, chills, and splenomegaly rather than a shrunken spleen. The history of recurrent hand swelling isn't typical for malaria.

 

Option C. Pancreatitis: Main symptoms include severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, unrelated to the symptoms described in the case.

 

Option D. Measles: Characterized by a rash, fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots, none of which relate to the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

In a child presenting with fever and recurrent hand swelling following physical activity, alongside a history of a shrunken spleen, sickle cell anemia should be considered a primary diagnosis. This highlights the importance of considering hemoglobinopathies in patients with peculiar skeletal pains and organ findings suggestive of chronic hemolytic processes.

 

Reference - Harrison 21 /Hemoglobinopathies/Chapter 98

questions.text: A female patient presented with the complaint of pain over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh after normal vaginal delivery. Which nerve is injured in this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral cutaneous nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, descending behind the inguinal ligament and running along the lateral part of the thigh, is the nerve likely injured in this clinical scenario.

The key clue is the patient's complaint of pain over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh following normal vaginal delivery. Compression of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh can lead to a condition called meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain along the lateral aspect of the thigh. The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh originates from the L2 and L3 nerve roots of the lumbar plexus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: Although the femoral nerve also has the same root values (L2, L3, L4) as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, it is formed by the posterior divisions of these nerves. The femoral nerve primarily supplies the hip joint, not the skin over the anterolateral thigh.

 

Option C. Obturator nerve: The obturator nerve is formed by the anterior divisions of the L2, L3, and L4 nerves. It mainly supplies the knee joint, and its referred pain is felt at the site of the femoral nerve. It is not responsible for the pain in the anterolateral thigh.

 

Option D. Gluteal nerve: The gluteal nerve is not related to the lumbar plexus or the anterolateral thigh region. It is not the nerve injured in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, originating from the L2 and L3 nerve roots, can be compressed, leading to meralgia paresthetica, which presents with burning pain, numbness & tingling over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh.
